chapterTitle: Return, Risk, and The Security Market Line

columns.text: This exercise asks us to determine the investments' expected returns and standard deviations.

The **expected return** is the net income or loss that an investor predicts on investments given known interest rates.

The **standard deviation** is a statistical measure of the distribution of values around the mean of a population. This is the variance's square root.

Let's first identify the given amounts in the problem: 


| | Amount$\hspace{5pt}$| 
|:--|--:| 
|Recession: ||
|Probability return | 10% | 
|Stock A's rate of return |4%|
|Stock B's rate of return |-17%|
|Normal: ||
|Probability return |60%|
|Stock A's rate of return |9%|
|Stock B's rate of return |12%|
|Boom: ||
|Probability return | 30%| 
|Stock A's rate of return|17%|
|Stock B's rate of return |27%|

The **expected return** is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected return}&=\sum_{\text{}}{\text{}_{R}} {\text{PR $\times$ R}}
\end{aligned}$$

Where: 

PR = Probability return \
R = Return

First, let us determine the expected return of Stock A. This is computed using the formula from step 4. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected return}&= {\text{(10\% $\times$ 4\%) + (60\% $\times$ 9\%) + (30\% $\times$ 17\%)}}\\
&= {\text{0.40\% + 5.40\% + 5.10\%}}\\
&= {\textbf{10.90\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The expected return of Stock A is 10.90%.**

Next, let us determine the expected return of Stock B. This is computed using the formula from step 4. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected return}&= {\text{[10\% $\times$ (-17\%)] + (60\% $\times$ 12\%) + (30\% $\times$ 27\%)}}\\
&= {\text{(-1.70\%) + 7.20\% + 8.10\%}}\\
&= {\textbf{13.60\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The expected return of Stock B is 13.60%.**

Then, we need to calculate the volatility of the stocks over the period. However, it would be best if you determined the variance first. We can determine the standard deviation by finding the square root of the variance. 

The variance of the stock's return is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{V}&={\sum_\text{}} {\text{PR $\times$(R - AR)}^\text{ 2}}
\end{aligned}$$

Where: \
PR = Probability return\
T = Year\
R = Realized return \
V = Variance

Let us compute the variance of Stock A using the formula from step 7. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{array}{l}
\text{V}=  {\text{[10\% $\times$ (4\% - 10.90\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}} + {\text{[60\% $\times$ (9\% - 10.90\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}} \\[5pt]
\hspace{20pt}{\text{+ [30\% $\times$ (17\% - 10.90\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}}\\

\hspace{10pt}= {\textbf{0.001809}}
\end{array}$$

**The variance of Stock A is 0.001809.**

Then, let us compute the variance of Stock B using the formula from step 7. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{array}{l}
\text{V}=  {\text{[10\% $\times$ (-17\% - 13.60\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}} + {\text{[60\% $\times$ (12\% - 13.60\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}} \\[5pt]
\hspace{20pt}+ {\text{[30\% $\times$ (27\% - 13.60\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}}\\
\hspace{10pt}= {\textbf{0.014904}}
\end{array}$$

**The variance of Stock B is 0.014904.**
